text: everyone in southern Louisiana from the
shrimp fishermen in Venice to the
backroads bait casters of cocoa tree is
wondering the same thing what could the
oil spill here mean I just can't imagine
not being able to fish are each shrimp
or oysters each of those species depend
on the marshlands that fan out across
the Mississippi Delta here this is an
incredibly productive ecosystem it's one
of the most productive ecosystems in the
country it's also one of the most
endangered ecosystems in the country
biologist Alexandra Coker studies these
wetlands which look healthy but are
actually sinking at the rate of a
football field an hour we are losing a
massive amount of land in south
Louisiana roughly eighty to ninety
percent of all the wetland loss that
occurs in the United States occurs here
in Louisiana when the oil when oil
strikes the system this system it's
going to be striking a system that is
already stressed and is already under
threat so far no oil has reached these
marshes in Terrebonne Bay but if another
that does it could spell disaster for
the grasses that literally hold these
islands together the oil can coat can
code everything down here right it can
coat coat the marsh plants it can coat
the sediment it could kill the marsh
plants it could kill all of the worms
and the like that are living here it
could kill the crabs that don't have
anywhere to go already damaged by too
much salt water from canals and erosion
the oil could be the last straw and as
the habitat diversity drops it becomes a
much less resilient Coast and it less
able to deal with environmental insults
environmental insults like a hurricane
whose damage a healthy marshland can
help lessen you know this is a Coast
where people live and work and that
brings in that's jobs and that's
livelihoods on the other hand you know
it also has a potential environmental
impacts as we as we are seeing
